turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Stewart, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Mr. Chief --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Richards -- I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: -- Chief Justice and Associate Justices.
At the outset, I never did answer Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question.
There is no way under the laws of the State of Texas that liquor can be transported in a private automobile through the State of Texas and interstate commerce.
That has been definitely decided for the reason that there is no permit which an individual can get to transport intoxicating liquor in private automobile.

In fact, this Court had before if not so very long ago, the case of Cartlidge versus Rainey from the Fifth Circuit which involve the transportation from the State of Arkansas through the State of Texas and to the State of Oklahoma of a private automobile loaded down to the gunnels with various bottles of intoxicating liquor.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You mean Mr. Richards that if he paid $100 could he -- he could not have taken this liquor with him?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: In the end -- in this individual case?
No, sir.
Not according to my theory which I'll try to --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Give $100 and leave the liquor there?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He would have to leave the liquor there.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: How would he get it across?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: How would he get it across?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He could get it across by getting a customs broker before it entered Texas to put it in bond, deliver it to a common carrier who's also under bond and then it should go in interstate commerce to its destination.
They would be no custom's duty if it was exempt.
He would of course have to pay the customs broker's fee and the common carrier's fee.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And also the tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, he would be exempt from tax.
No, Your Honor.

It's specifically provided in the -- any person authorized to export liquor from the state and having liquor intended for shipment from one place to a point outside must keep it in a separate compartment.
They gave them a little sort of a -- let's say fare or passport which shows that that is intended for export and no tax is due thereon.
The tax is a possessory or used tax.
It is not a duty.
It is for possession or used -- or use in the state now.

To continue my answer, that is the only way that I know that this liquor could be transported by the individual who is coming in to the customs and having it for his own personal use could bring it to the State of Texas.
There is no provision for making bond.
The legislature did not see fit to do it.
Now, the legislature did --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: By an individual.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: By an individual, yes, Your Honor

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you're saying is that Texas has legislation by which nobody in a private car can get liquor through the State of Texas?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It had nothing to do with the lot fee or --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Fee or any --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is prohibiting the carriage of liquor in private car.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Without the payment of the tax if he gets -- if he pay his tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Well, the -- there's a provision in the law that one -- one quart not to exceed one quart may be imported into the State of Texas, brought into the State of Texas but the stamp, the tax must be paid and the stamp to fix.
Now, the last legislature changed that so that non-residence of Texas could bring in not to exceed for a quart.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But beyond that --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That is the sole exemption.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- beyond that he -- he can pay a thousand dollars (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: And could not keep the liquor, no, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Richard's tell me.I don't quite follow it.
Why was that the -- that Texas then in phase of his declaration of intention to take it in North Carolina insisted on the payment of the tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't understand the mental processes of some of these agents of the Texas Liquor Control Board.

I do know that the law says that the -- in there at least the way they concede -- construe it, if you have liquor in the State of Texas to which no stamp has been affixed, no tax paid, it is an illegal beverage except that is all that which is in excess of one quart.
Therefore, he's subject to seizure.
Now, if he had brought one quart in there and has refused to pay the tax, he might be confronted with a different situation but he had exceeded.
He and his two companions each exceeded the allotment for personal use.
He said it was brought in for personal use.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then what should have happened, I gather on your theory is that each of them could have kept one bottle or three of them, weren't they?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think nothing would have been done if each one had kept one bottle.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And not (Voice Overlap) they accepted to have to pay the tax from the one bottle.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: They would have to pay -- the tax is levied on the fact that it was -- it was illegally possessed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But on the basis of his declaration that they're going to the North Carolina with it, it should have concede.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- everything of the three bottles.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Because they -- it would be unlawful for him to transport.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is the specific provision which translates legislatively what you said that this is a measure in keeping what the transportation through or in Texas of liquor by a private -- personal automobile?
Where is that provision?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: There is no provision, Your Honor.
That is judicial -- judicial interpretation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But where is this -- can you reverse to the decisions of your court?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I can refer you to a case of Bols versus State.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Bols?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Bol, B-O-L.
They are cited in my brief at -- glancing on page 5.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: 132 (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: 132, also the case of Chalmers versus State, 216 S.W. 2d 203.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And ultimately to Supreme Court of Criminal Appeals.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: By the Court of Criminal Appeals which is the Court of last -- last resort.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, (Voice Overlap) for our purpose, it is the law of Texas declared by Court of Criminal Appeals for our purpose of the law of Texas or written to your constitution.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That (Inaudible) or anybody and the Chief Justice driving from Texas (Inaudible) something that he can't have (Inaudible) anything.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor that is correct.
Now, in -- the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No matter what he pays?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, matter what he pay.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If -- in other words, this man had paid $1.40 a gallon on his 11 bottles, he still could --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He still could not have taken it, no, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not only that but he would be -- he would --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He would still be subject to fine because he had imported more than the exempted provision.
I think that this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, this isn't -- it's not -- I don't know where to take this -- but this is not a fiscal tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, the tax incidentally is a regulatory tax primarily.
Now, the taxes are divided in two sections.
I have not cited those in my brief because I -- although I should have.
I will admit that I was in error not so doing.
We have the permit fees, the license fees.
Those are solely a revenue measures.
They go one-fourth for the permanent school fund and three-fourth to the old age assistance.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Licensing whom for what?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: For the wholesalers, the retailers, the position --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The people (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, the people in business.
I'm sure in case of an occupation of dealing with it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: The -- this tax which is denominated as a sales tax but which is in fact a possession or used tax.

It is primarily regulatory tax and after the expenses of the enforcement of the Liquor Control Act have been -- that which the legislature choose to appropriate for that purpose have been expended and then the balance goes into the general fund and maybe used for other purposes.
I think that there's an allocation, one-fourth additional of that for the school fund.
The tax is generally -- the stamp is generally fixed by the retailer in the package store before he sells it.
And to that extent, it's a sales tax but if I bring it in from Arkansas as in the case of Chalmers.
He brought them from Louisiana.
He brought it in with the United -- with the federal stamp attached, the Louisiana stamp attached.
But no Texas stamp so it was seized.
He didn't have a permit to transport it within the State of Texas in private automobile.
That is a case in Bols versus State.

Now, there is an old case, Horton versus State where the man had in his possession, not quite a quart, and under the law before it was amended, you were allowed to import one quart in without the payment of any tax.
That law was later on amended and required with the proviso that provide the tax be paid and the stamp be affixed.
The Court in that case said that he is -- the Court under the -- within the exempt of provision.
He was not guilty of any offense.

In other words, the States contention in here is bottomed on effect the -- if the importer had brought this in as an import to be transported in interstate commerce any tax that we would attempt to levy upon him would be void.
It would plainly be a burden on interstate commerce.
But the amount that he brought in made itself ipso facto contraband and the fact that he had possession of it and could not get a permit to transport in -- in interstate commerce to North Carolina.
It was still contraband.
Therefore, it was subject to the tax.
That is on the basis of his possession.
He had it in there illegally.
Now, that is the gist of the State's case.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This is a -- excuse me.
Is this a fine from possession or --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: It is a fine for the possession of unstamped liquor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not a tax at all?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, sir.
It's a -- it's a -- in a way it is.
It's a -- it's a tax on the possession of unstamped liquor.
You might say it's a fine.
It might be a civil fine as opposed to the criminal penalty of the $100 for having possession of it.
There's a criminal penalty for transporting or having in your possession any illegal beverages.
This is an illegal beverage because it's not stamped.
I realize the fact that what Your Honor I think his question direct to me is why -- why catch an illegal beverage.
Well, the possession of an illegal beverage I think is always been subject to a tax.

As a matter of fact, I don't have the citation right with me but prior to the -- or during the prohibition here, the State of Pennsylvania have what they call the floor tax for the possession of beverages which was illegal to possess.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This is an unusual way to levy a fine without a trial of any kind, just collect $100 off hand.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, that was a criminal trial, Your Honor.
The -- the tax -- he didn't -- he had not paid the possessory tax.
If he paid the possessory tax, he could not have been prosecuted.
He was prosecuted for the possession of unstamped liquor which is an illicit beverage.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: It was determined not taxed or failure to pay a tax but merely --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: If -- for the possession only.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Possession only?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: For the possession only.

They -- if you'll recall, the counsel said that he -- they took him back to the bridge again and offered him the opportunity to pay the tax which he refused standing on his -- what he alleged to be his constitutional rights.
So then, he was arrested.
The liquor was confiscated and he was tried before a jury.
And the issues were submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And issue was not appended to pay the tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: The possession of -- of 11 gallons of unstamped liquor which is a possession of an illegal beverage.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Contrary to law?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Contrary to law, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Not because he had failed to pay in taxes.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So that in effect, I gather, he could not encourage himself of the offense even if subsequently he had paid the tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think that if he -- no, not after the -- he couldn't have purged himself after the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you didn't have to take him back to the bridge and give him (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I don't think that was necessary.
He had the opportunity and he stood on his alleged constitutional rights.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Tell me.
Does any of Texas position depend on the Twenty-First Amendment?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is the position that you're asserting for Texas depend in anyways under the Twenty-First Amendment?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your honor.
The whole Texas Liquor Control Act is based on the Twenty-First Amendment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Have we had a case in -- did this Court have occasion to construe delivery in the Twenty-First Amendment to include physical (Inaudible) coming into a State and transfer it to another State.
Do we have a case --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I have not -- I am trying to read all the cases that this opinion, this Court has written on the Twenty-First Amendment and that question -- as a matter of fact, the -- there are not many cases on the tax question.
I think the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you -- your -- this statute according to what you've told us of the rulings of your court, raises a question whether the Twenty-First Amendment giving Texas power to deal with liquor brought -- for delivery or use (Inaudible) does bring into play what the delivery covers within the scope of that Amendment.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, I think it does, definitely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there any like many or a few opinions that had been written by this Court?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, sir.
Your Honor, I -- I have cite --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Carter -- Carter case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In Carter in which --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: There is a case which was just -- which were decided on October 29th by the Tenth Circuit Murphy versus Love which according to gossip will eventually reach this Court.
There's a divided court there, however, that was not directly on this point.
It brings into effect the -- into play the amendment and the federal enclave at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas.
I don't know whether the Court is familiar with it or not or whether the Court would care to have me discuss it or not.
Well, it does bear on it to -- to an -- in a certain degree.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it must be your confession that this is not (Voice Overlap) the holding of a (Inaudible) giving Texas regular authoritative power over liquors within its physical confines, includes liquor that it is only (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, definitely that is the basis of the Cartlidge versus Rainey, the Duckworth case and the Ziffrin case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, let me put it to in other way Mr. Richards.
Does that depend also on our concluding that delivery does include possession under these circumstances that delivery within the meaning of the Twenty-First Amendment?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: My â€“- I don't know whether I follow Your Honor's question.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, what I mean is with -- unless this regulation authorized by the Twenty-First Amendment.
Does your case fall?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I would say that it did.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You say that it does?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I would say that it did, definitely.
I think that the power which is the legislature is delegated to the Liquor Control Board under the Liquor Control Act is definitely a product of the Twenty-First Amendment.

It was the intention of the legislature, I think, to prevent any liquor from being brought into the State of Texas from -- for use or sale or dispose of unless it came to the proper channels and unless a tax had been paid.
Now, as it happens at the -- usually the tax is affixed by the retailer to the bottle before the sold to the purchaser.
That's in a package store and the package stores are the only ones who have the right to sell liquor in the original package.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And what is the limit, Mr. Richards if they sell on those package stores?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: As much as you can pay for I think.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There's no limit.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No limit.
No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There's no limit on how -- how it's transported?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, you -- except that it cannot be transported from a wet area to a dry area.
That is the section which counsel quoted 666-23 (a).

It can be transported from a place where it's authorized to be sold to another place where it's authorized to be used which would be from one wet county to another one, but it can't be transported from a wet county and to a dry county.
If it is, it's subject to seizure, stamped or unstamped.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you a question?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let me see if I fully understand that (Inaudible) of your law as a regulatory measure for a judgment of Twenty-First Amendment.
I understand that liquor can be transported through the state if certain authorized (Inaudible) transported.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, without the payment of a tax.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does that extend beyond recognized common carriers such as a railroad or a trucking company?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think that there is a provision that a contract carrier may.We have a difference in -- in automobile carriers.
We have what's called a common carrier.
We have specialized carriers and we have a contract carrier.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I was -- what I was wondering was, has the State of Texas set up for itself a new category of carrier if they need certain qualification of Texas and transport it through the State and interstate commerce or does that merely apply for a recognized common carrier to the now existing (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Now, I can read if Your Honor will permit me, I can read the definition of carrier.
The word carrier when used in this section shall mean and include water carriers, airplane lines.

All steam, electric motor power railway carriers and common carrier and motor carriers operating under (Inaudible) convinced necessity issued by the Railroad Commission of Texas or by certificates issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The holders of such certificates shall be authorized to transport liquor into and out of the State and points within this -- and between points within the State.
Such carrier shall furnish such information concerning the transportation of liquor as maybe required by the Board.
The annual state fee for carrier permits should be $5.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Now, that -- that differs from the Ziffrin case and that a common carrier holding the certificate from the federal -- under the Federal Motor Carrier Act doesn't have to get a state permit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do I understand the (Inaudible) of the regulation of the State seeks to interpose (Inaudible) interstate commerce insofar as attempting to limit transportation through the State to the recognized common carrier.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I think that is definite.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That is not on a tax basis --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Not on a tax basis, no.
No, Your Honor, that's not on the tax basis.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The State of Texas evidently claimed as I understand the (Inaudible) its power to do that under the Court -- the Amendment.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Rather than -- and admits that the related issues or something else that -- that regulation would be permitted by the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black

I understand now that they're going to take the (Inaudible) it has to be done by common carriers.
Suppose a man just want to drive to Texas.
Can he bring liquor -- a bottle of liquor in --

turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards

Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black

turn.speaker: c_k_richards

turn.text: He can carry it all the way through.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He can carry it all the way through and that quite frequently is done.
That quite frequently is done.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that what you have is a prohibition against transporting liquors through the State of Texas in excess of one quart.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: In excess of one quart.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And unless, it is transported through --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: On -- with a permit.
Yes, that is quite true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why isn't this (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren

turn.text: But let me -- let me ask you this Mr. Richards, suppose -- suppose a man went to -- to one of your store, one of your package store and you said there was no limit on what he could buy.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren

turn.text: But they get through the State analysis.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think he could do so.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: One other question I'd like to ask --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Provided with stamp, of course it would be stamped if he bought it from a package store.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
One other question I'd like to ask you is that -- that permit that you spoke of that goes to common carriers --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and so forth.
I -- I understood you to say that the cost of that permit is only $5.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So it's purely a regular (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Purely a regular store.
The -- the entire scheme of the Liquor Control Act is regulation.
I might state that it is -- as counsel said there are several features in there that seem to contradict themselves.
But this law was compromised between the wet and the dry thought.
It's a -- it's a sort of a hybrid.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Richards, I'm troubled by one thing --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- and maybe you can help me.
You have stated that this fine imposed upon petitioner was not for failure to pay a tax but for merely having possession which was illegal under the local law.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is the petitioner then, getting down to this particular case, guilty of the offense charged in the information which says that he had in -- in his possession, a rum, both now in the container to which no tax stamps showing the payment of the tax on said beverage due to State of Texas was affixed and to which so unstamped container, is this literally being read, no valid evidence was affixed showing a payment of the tax on such beverage due to the State of Texas and the tax stamp was then and there required by the laws of Texas to be affixed to such container and the tax on such beverage was then and there due to the State of Texas and the tax imposed to the laws of the State of Texas on such illicit beverage had not been paid all against the piece of dignity of the State.

Now -- and the question, isolating our attention to this particular case, does this information charge a violation of the law?In this particular case, says he is guilty because he failed to pay the tax, isn't it?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: As I read the law and as I've just stated to the Court, I -- the law is rather next step.
The illicit beverage is defined in 666-3 (a) which is on page 16 of the appendix.

The illicit beverages shall mean and refer to any alcoholic beverages possessed imported or transported in violation in this Act or on which any tax imposed to the laws of the State has not been paid and the tax stamped affixed thereto.

Now, no person shall import into the State any liquor in excess of one quart from any source unless a permit be first obtained from the Board and any person so purchasing or importing liquor in violation in this Section shall be subject to penalties here and after provide.
And here comes the carriers.

Now, for tax purposes only, this is 666-1732, protects purposes on a distilled spirits contained in the container having attached thereto the federal liquor strip stamp or imported from any foreign country.
I hereby subject to trans -- to taxation and must have affixed thereto the appropriate Texas tax stamp for the distilled spirits.
Now, that's for tax purposes only.
First, they say that the illicit beverage is one which is possessed which doesn't have the tax stamp on it.
And subsequently, they say that anything that is imported from a foreign country must have the tax stamp on it and if it doesn't have the tax stamp on it then its contraband.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And if -- and according to your statement, this couldn't have -- you couldn't get any tax stamp possessed because a private person bringing in liquor cannot get legalized right to bring it to (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that no tax is paid to be sure but he couldn't possibly pay it.
But nevertheless, you say it contraband because he is a fellow who can't get a tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He can't get it.
Now, that -- if the -- the indictment or the information here does not specify the number of quart, it says he had in his possession out and the illicit beverage as defined under the Act.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But to sustain your -- your conviction, you have to show not only possession of this liquor but --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That -- that the tax had not been paid.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: That the tax had not been paid and therefore he must also show that the tax could have been paid if it wasn't -- that this was a valid tax, you can charge him with -- with the -- of having unstamped liquor and -- and there's no -- no validity of the stamp.You have to show both the possession of the liquor and the --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That it was subject to tax.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: -- valid tax.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Under this information?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Under the information, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And he couldn't have got the stamps.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: He could have got one stamp.
He --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: For -- for one gallon.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, sir.
No, sir, he could not have get -- I --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He didn't need it for one gallon.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: It would seem as --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One quart.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: As I say, Your Honor, the meeting place upon this by the agents of the Liquor Control Board is that everything inside has got to have a stamp on it willy-nilly that it -- I fail to see any reason why the -- anything in excess of one quart to each person was not the imported if provided it was not in interstate commerce in violation along with subject to seizure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but if your court -- if the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas says that a fellow who has in his possession liquor without appropriate stamp, had violated the statute and it is no defense that he is a fellow who couldn't possibly get a stamp because he is forbidden from carrying it at all but the determination is not reviewable by this Court.
That's the local law of Texas.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: But he's not -- he's not forbidden from possessing if he put a stamp.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: If he puts a stamp.
No, Your Honor.
I think he would be -- I think Your Honor, I think he would be prohibited by law from possessing more than one quart which is imported from Mexico --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: -- or any -- any state of the -- the United States.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that needed no stamp.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That would have needed stamps, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: With that one quart?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No -- yes, sir, that would have needed stamps also.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well Mr. Richards, can this conviction be supported under the language of this information merely on the proof that at least one quart if he was entitle to one quart, stamped, he could have carried it through Texas but he'd need -- he did not have even one quart stamp.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think that he could.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I suppose you would probably argue that it's against the law of whatever liquor in Texas that's not stamped (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Period, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then you would say that it doesn't excuse a man of that violation to prove on his part that he can't establish because he's cared to do it.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That's -- that's exactly my contention.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: An early suggestion and early words from the appellant, but is there any suggestion that this conviction offense the Due Process Clause because he was convicted procedurally for the wrong thing?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No, Your Honor, the only thing that I have answered -- attempted to answer in the state's brief is that it's not an export-import tax and it wasn't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And it's as if (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: -- it's not an interstate commerce and that's all the sufficiency of the information.
It has never been great.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All the satisfaction of the -- of the information of -- of the status -- the adequacy of evidence to satisfy the information as before.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That isn't before, no, Your Honor.
Now, in six --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You've got any doubt (Inaudible)
It's not in the question raised that this liquor didn't have to be taxed (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It was still liquor?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: It was still liquor if it exceeded the alcoholic content that was required to the tax.
Now the --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: How could he get stamps?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: -- in answer to -- in answer to Your Honor's question, 666-23a (4) it provides -- it is provided that any person may bring into this State not more than one quart of liquor for his own personal use.
That's the way the law used to be.
Then they added this, provided further that he shall pay and affix thereto the required state tax stamps.

Now, the legislature in its wisdom, the last session I think, has increased I don't know whether I stated this before or not, has increased the -- the amount allowable to a non-resident of Texas to four quarts.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the argument of that?
I want to know.

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: People from outside the State --

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- more liquor than people in Texas?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: I hardly believe that is true, Your Honor.

I think that it's been the price that the (Voice Overlap) there and it hurts the Chambers of Commerce that the people coming to Texas, they prefer to go to some other State where that -- port of entry where that doesn't affect it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In order to do that, you've got the whole country sold up though.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: Well, Tijuana is still with us and I think there are ports of entry in New Mexico, I think it's very small and there are two in Arizona, Douglas and Nogales.
What -- they require that military personnel, this amendment requires that military personnel stationed in Texas are restricted to one quart only.
Military personnel living outside the State or outside the State of Texas may bring in four quarts.
This whole Texas Liquor Control Act is a -- is a product of trial and error so to speak.
It's amended that every session in the legislature one way or another depending on the amount of pressure brought by the various forces.

Briefly, in order to conclude my argument, I don't think that any of the cases cited by counsel for the appellant or after the board, I think all the export-import tax cases I think it's good -- they're a good law but they're all ad valorem cases.
And there's no question that the findings of the Court particularly in that (Inaudible) case.
That was where the liquor was being assembled from outside of California, came to rest in the warehouse for export to the Hawaiian Islands.They attempted to let the ad valorem tax on it.
A great question before the Court was there whether that had come to rest and not to -- a tax could be -- would attach.
(Inaudible) case with the converse of that, that was importation into California and again there was the ad valorem tax.
To my mind, the Carter case is -- and the Duckworth cases are in our support.
The Jamison case that counsel cited was a case that arose under the read amendment which was purely against the transportation from dry to wet state.
The man had five quarts and he was transporting it by a private automobile.

The matter that was before this Court seemed to be that he said that those were of his own personal use and the Court's majority opinion said that it was immaterial whether it's his personal use or not.

And Mr. Justice Clark, not the present Mr. Justice Clark, but his predecessor, dissented, stating that he thought that since it was for his personal use, that it was excluded from the Commerce Clause, it's the Commerce --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That was on page 21?

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That was -- that was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: c_k_richards
turn.label: Mr. C. K. Richards
turn.text: That was a pre-Twenty-First Amendment case.
We -- I fail to find any cases.
Our case here is bottomed on this Cartlidge versus Rainey that the transportation was illegal.
That is he couldn't go to Texas, therefore it was contraband.
Now, the fact that -- I think the State of Texas should afford some relief to a person who is coming through as a bona fide tourist and intends that for his own personal use.
The fact is the legislature is not seemed fit to do it except for these one and now four quart exemption.
We think that the conviction being for the possession of an illegal beverage, the illegal beverage being that which is not stamped.
And since it was not in interstate commerce, the conviction should be affirmed.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and gentlemen.
I would like to clear up something that seems to have puzzled you as I see it.

The information in this particular case charged possession, illegal possession of the liquor and that the reason that possession was illegal was because the appellant herein had not paid the stamp tax due on that liquor.
If he had paid the stamp tax and affixed it on the bottle, he never would have been charged.
That was the sole point for the Court that he had not paid the tax, consequently, his possession was illegal because the tax was not paid.
He claimed that the tax was not valid, therefore he was not -- he did not need to pay the tax.
And if he did not need to pay the tax, he could not be charge with illegal possession of the liquor for -- for not having tax payments on it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What is the fact -- what is the law rather if he had paid the tax?
Do you contend that he could have transported it?

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, sir.

In fact that was -- this is going outside of the record perhaps but as long as the tourist prior to the decision set down by the Court of Criminal Appeals, paid the tax, any known which they were from they could bring in four quarts of liquor, pay the tax and transport through the State of Texas.
That was done in custody.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Stewart.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Could Texas obtain liquor from coming in at all?
Could Texas say make himself a prohibition state for his own people and interest of enforcement of effectiveness involved or any liquor coming in from many other states or from any foreign countries.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: For use and delivery therein, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But not in transit across.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: They are in transit across.
I don't think so.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: That's basically your argument.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you're sure that liquor in fact would not be used or delivered therein, isn't there some room for state regulation as to the method by which -- that which it is said shall be carried across the State?
They may be assured will be carried across the State?

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: I think they could devise a method, yes sir, I think so.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, for example --

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: They could --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- suppose the State could say that you may carry it across here.
We think that reasonably to be sure it doesn't stop here and isn't delivered here and it isn't used here.
It may go across only by common carrier in the bond.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: I think they could even do this that they could say for instance, you can bring this liquor through, we will stamp it or we will seal it.
And you report at the Texas border where you leave the State of Texas, if you -- you have used any liquor then you pay the tax.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, but can't -- may they not -- I'm assuming the question Justice Frankfurter put to you, it's completely dry state.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And may not a state that it is a completely dry state say that if you say you're going to take it across into another state just to be sure that you do, we insist that it go by common carrier in bond.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: I don't think they could for this reason that the Congress has passed legislation saying that they may import that.
And that since Congress has acted the State cannot deny the person the right to bring in that gallon of liquor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what's the meaning of Twenty-First Amendment?

Certainly, it must allow some leeway to a state, doesn't it, to regulate, to assure that there shall be no delivery or use of liquor that they do not want to be delivered or used in the State without regard to what the Congress has done?

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, sir.
But in this instance, I think -- I think that's what this Court has held that they may regulate, for instance in the Carter case.

They require that person to -- and incidentally, this was commercial transportation involved in the Carter case, in the Duckworth case and all cases that were cited by Mr. Richards, were all commercial transportation say 150 cases, a thousand cases of liquors such as that.
The State in those instances required a bond and they required a route designation showing the route that they will pass through in that State.
And this Court said that that was a reasonable regulation in absence of any action by the federal congress.
And each instance, the Court has qualified in his opinion by saying in absence of any regulation by Congress and I think here we have the regulation by Congress.
The Congress has assumed that the person returning from a foreign country may bring in one quart of liquor free.
Since it's an import, he has a right to carry it to his destination without interference from the State on the border.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Stewart.

turn.speaker: b_r_stewart
turn.label: Mr. B. R. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What have you to say in respect to Justice Frankfurter's question put to Mr. Richards that if this fine was -- find him guilty and was made and the fine imposed upon a wrong ground, namely, refusal to pay a tax, not mainly for possession -- no, the other way around, refusal to pay a tax when it should have been on possession that such as inadequate state ground decision and we have no jurisdiction.
